hits.snippet: Some who emphasized the humanity of Christ debated with Apollinarius. The Nestorians asserted that the two natures of Christ, divinity and humanity, are distinct and are not mingled. The theology of Antioch believed the same all the more. The theology of [19] Alexandria, on the other hand, emphasized the divinity of Christ and even called Mary the Mother of God. Both were too extreme. Nestorius, a patriarch of Constantinople, was originally from the school in Antioch. When some presbyters under this school asserted that Mary was the mother not of Christ’s divinity but only of His humanity, he strongly supported them. Nestorius overemphasized the distinctiveness of Christ’s divinity and humanity; he even claimed that in the body of Jesus were two persons, God and man. This is the source of the error of Nestorianism. Cyril, the bishop of Alexandria, opposed this doctrine. The emperor of both the East and the West convened the third council in Ephesus in A.D. 431. The council rejected the Nestorian doctrine, considering it a heresy, but it did not explain the relationship between the two natures of Christ. Moreover, it stressed divinity over humanity. Later, Eutychius, an archimandrite of a monastery at Constantinople, asserted the merging of Christ’s two natures, with humanity being merged into divinity, making Him an extraordinary person. The archbishop Flavian of Constantinople renounced the claim. Eutychius did not listen and was thus removed from his office. However, Dioscorus of Alexandria appealed on behalf of Eutychius. The bishops still maintained that the doctrine was in disagreement with the Scriptures, and they called for a council to renounce the teaching as heresy. However, the emperor was displeased and later convoked another council in Ephesus in A.D. 449. The bishop of Alexandria led soldiers and presbyters to attend, exiled the bishops of Constantinople and Antioch, and even attacked and caused chaos at the council. Flavian died from major injuries. This council was known as the Robbers’ Council and is not listed as one of the ecumenical councils. Later, the fourth council was assembled in Constantinople (Chalcedon) in A.D. 451. At this time the Monophysites slightly changed their teaching, saying that although the humanity of Jesus was inferior, through its merging with divinity it had become a new nature that was different from either one. Based on a letter of Leo, the bishop of Rome, to Flavian, the council declared that Christ is one person with two natures, and the two natures are unconfused, unchangeable, indivisible, and inseparable. He is the complete God and the perfect man. Later, the Monophysites still contested with the orthodox school, and a fifth council was convened in Constantinople in A.D. 553. At the time when Constantine the Great came into power, Christianity was prevailing around the Mediterranean, and the contentions among Christians became a problem. As a result of Constantine’s desire to unify the Roman Empire, he called a conference at Nicaea in A.D. 325. At that council, the Council of Nicaea, Arius and his heresy were condemned. The result of that council brought about only a temporary situation of peace, for problem after problem occurred from that [322] time onward. Sometime later, the papal system was established, resulting in a situation of darkness until the time of the Reformation. Before the Reformation, laymen were not allowed to interpret the Bible, but with the Reformation came the open Bible. When the Bible became open, the arguments began a second time.

hits.book_ref: CWWL, 1988, vol. 2, "The Leading of the New Testament Ministry and the Organic Work of the New Way," ch. 1: Being Perfected and Equipped for the Advance of the New Way
hits.snippet: Colossians 1:15 says that Christ, the Son of God’s love (v. 13), is the Firstborn of all creation. Firstborn in Greek is prototokos. Proto means “the first,” and tokos means “born.” We have consulted many Bible versions, and this verse is always translated according to the original text as “the Firstborn of all creation.” However, most expositors of the Bible do not dare to speak of this verse directly according to the original text. This is because in the second century Arius misunderstood this verse, claiming that Christ was only a creature and that His divinity was not complete. Thus, Arius was judged as a heretic by the church. As a result, no one dared to use this verse to speak of the humanity of Christ.

hits.book_ref: Life-study of Exodus, msg. 158: The Holy Anointing Oil  (2)
hits.snippet: The four spices signify humanity in God’s creation. In the Bible the number four signifies God’s creation. We have the four living creatures and the four corners of the earth. Furthermore, the four spices themselves are elements of God’s creation. These spices signify the humanity of the Lord Jesus. In His incarnation the Lord Jesus was both God and man. The four spices signify the humanity of the Lord Jesus in God’s creation. Of course, some Christians do not like to hear [1690] the word creation used in the case of the Lord Jesus. This is due to the heretical teaching of Arius who taught that Christ was merely a created being, and that He was not the eternal God.

hits.book_ref: Life-study of Luke, msg. 76: The Man-savior's Ascension  (1)
hits.snippet: As the One inaugurated into His heavenly office through His ascension, the Man-Savior has a wonderful status. He is both God and man, both the Creator and a creature. Some theologians would agree that Christ is God, man, and the Creator, but would deny the fact that He is also a creature. However, Colossians 1:15 says that Christ is the Firstborn of all creation, indicating that with respect to His humanity He is a creature. But due to the heresy of Arius, which was condemned at the Council of Nicea in A.D. 325, many are reluctant to say that, according to Colossians 1:15, Christ is a creature. In this verse we are told that Christ is the image of God, the Firstborn of all creation. If this verse were not in the Bible, we would not presume to say that Christ is both the Creator and a creature. However, this verse is the basis for saying that Christ is a creature as well as the Creator.

hits.book_ref: CWWL, 1973–1974, vol. 1, "The History of the Church and the Local Churches," ch. 1: The History of the Church (1)
hits.snippet: The defenders of the truth attempted to clear up the different opinions concerning the person of Christ. This resulted in Christology, which is the study of who Christ is, the study of Christ’s Person. Arius was a heretical teacher who said that Christ was a creature but that He was not the Creator. The council assembled at Nicaea in A.D. 325 declared Arianism a heresy and rejected it. The Nicene Creed stresses that God is triune, that the Godhead has three persons—the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit. Many, however, unconsciously and subconsciously believe that there are three separate Gods. They do not understand that God is triune, not for doctrinal study or debate but for the dispensing of Himself into His chosen and redeemed people.

hits.book_ref: CWWL, 1975–1976, vol. 3, "Various Anaheim Lord's Day Evening Meetings," ch. 3: The Human Spirit and the Triune God
hits.snippet: Modalism was taught by Sabellius and had been defeated by the time the orthodox creed was formulated at the first Council of Nicaea. Modalism claims that the Father ceased to exist when the Son came and that the Son was no longer after the Spirit came at Pentecost. The Nicene Creed repudiates modalism and also condemns [233] the heresy of Arius, who taught that Christ was not eternally God but merely a creature who became the Son of God. Arianism leads to tritheism—the belief that the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit are three separate Gods. Many who criticize us subconsciously believe that there are three Gods. In the past we may have held this belief secretly or unconsciously.

hits.book_ref: CWWL, 1978, vol. 1, "The Present Need Among the Churches in the Lord's Recovery," ch. 3: The Need to See and Keep the Genuine Oneness as the Nature of the Lord's Recovery
hits.snippet: When the New Testament was written, the church was still one, but by the second century it had been divided by the doctrinal disputes of the church fathers. With the exception of the heretics Arius and Nestorius, the church fathers were sound, fundamental teachers, but their disputes caused the oneness of the Body to be lost. In A. D. 325 the emperor Constantine called the Council of Nicaea, which used the authority of the Roman Empire to outwardly reunite the church. The Nicene Creed was produced not by the Spirit but by an earthly, evil authority. This was not a genuine recovery but a falsehood. The word catholic means “universal and uniquely one.” By the sixth century the Roman Catholic Church was fully formed as a counterfeit.

hits.book_ref: CWWL, 1980, vol. 2, "Fellowship with Serving Ones," ch. 8: The Battle for the Recovery of the Truth
hits.snippet: In the first few centuries there were several heretical schools of teaching concerning Christology, which is the study of the Person of Christ. One school said that Christ has a divine nature without the human nature. Another school, led by Arius, said that Christ has a human nature without the divine nature. A third school said that these two natures were mingled together in Christ to produce a third nature, which was no longer truly human or divine.

hits.book_ref: CWWL, 1982, vol. 1, "The Ministry of the New Covenant Being the Ministry of the Spirit, Righteousness, and Reconciliation," ch. 1: Two Matters concerning Christ's Person
hits.snippet: Another heresy originated with Arius, who taught that Christ was not fully God but merely the first and foremost of God’s creatures and that He became God after resurrecting. Although Colossians 1:15 calls Christ “the Firstborn of all creation,” since Arius’s condemnation, Bible teachers do not dare to teach that Christ is a creature. However, to deny that Christ is a creature is to deny that He truly became a man. First John 4:2 says, “In this you know the Spirit of God: Every spirit which confesses that Jesus Christ has come in the flesh is of God.” As God, Christ is self-existing and ever-existing. To be created or born implies that the created or born one previously did not exist. Although Christ is the ever-existing God, the Bible also teaches that He was born as a man, thus becoming a creature. The Bible and God are not limited by our narrow notion of time. For example, Revelation 13:8 says that Christ the Lamb “was slain from the foundation of the world.” We need to put aside our religious concepts, which are based on traditional teachings, and receive the pure revelation of the Bible.

hits.book_ref: CWWL, 1986, vol. 3, "The Revelation and Vision of God," ch. 4: Concerning the Divine Trinity (4)
hits.snippet: Since Christ is a creature in His humanity, when was He created? Arius asserted that since Christ is a creature, He is not the eternal [383] God, but He was created by God at a certain period in eternity as the first created One. Hence, in this thought there was a time when Christ did not exist. This is a great heresy. Colossians 1:15b says that Christ is “the Firstborn of all creation.” This means that, in God’s eternal plan, in God’s eternal economy, the Triune God agreed that the Son would become a man, would become flesh. From that time on, in the eyes of God, the Son has been a creature. Then, in time, He actually came to be a man.
